```{block, note-text, type='rmdnote'}
* You do not need to purchase a text for this course.
* Please bring a notebook and pencil to every class. 
* Be prepared to actively participate and collaborate.
* Access the [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com) assignments via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).
```


## Week 01 (Jan 16, Jan 18) {-}

* Watch the video ["The History of S and R"](https://youtu.be/jk9S3RTAl38) (~10 minutes)

* Watch the video ["Introduction to the R Language"](https://youtu.be/APm4SxJx0eg) (~30 minutes)

* Read textbook [Section 1. Introduction](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/introduction.html).

* Read textbook [Section 4. Workflow: Basics](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/workflow-basics.html).

* Read textbook [Section 20. Vectors](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/vectors.html).

* Read Stat545 ["The many flavors of R objects"](http://stat545.com/block004_basic-r-objects.html).

* Sign up for a free account on [GitHub](https://github.com).

* When you register for a free individual GitHub account, request a [student discount](https://education.github.com) to obtain a few private repositories as well as unlimited public repositories.  Please use something similar to **FirstnameLastname** as your username when you register with GitHub.  For example, my username on GitHub is *jillthomley*. If you have a popular name such as John Smith, you may need to add some other distinguishing character to your username.   

* Complete _Introduction to R_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).
 
```{block, week1note, type='rmdnote'}
* Take notes as you work though the DataCamp modules. The goal is to learn, not just finish!
* RStudio has helpful [Cheat Sheets](https://www.rstudio.com/resources/cheatsheets/)! You may want to start with _Base R_ and _R Markdown Reference Guide_.
```
 
```{block, week1optional, type='rmdoptional'}
Optional

You may want to install [Git](http://git-scm.com/downloads), [R](http://cran.r-project.org), [RStudio](http://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/), [zotero](https://www.zotero.org), and optionally [$LaTeX$](http://www.ctan.org/starter) on your personal computer. If you do, you will want to follow Jenny Bryan's excellent advice for [installing R and RStudio](http://stat545-ubc.github.io/block000_r-rstudio-install.html) and [installing Git](http://stat545-ubc.github.io/git01_git-install.html).  Jenny's advice is also in chapters 6 and 7 of _[Happy Git and GitHub for the useR](http://happygitwithr.com/)_.  Note that [Git](http://git-scm.com/downloads), [R](http://cran.r-project.org), [RStudio](http://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/), and [$LaTeX$](http://www.ctan.org/starter) are all installed on the [Appstate RStudio](https://mathr.math.appstate.edu/) server.

Watch the following videos as appropriate:

* [Install R on Mac (2 min)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lJxVRgiX-ik)    
* [Install R for Windows (3 min)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LII6of-5Odw)    
* [Install R and RStudio on Windows (5 min)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eD07NznguA4)    
```


## Week 02 (Jan 23, Jan 25) {-}

* Read textbook [Section 6. Workflow: Scripts](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/workflow-scripts.html).

* Read textbook [Section 18. Pipes](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/pipes.html).

* Read textbook [Section 19. Functions](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/functions.html).

* Read textbook [Section 21. Iteration](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/iteration.html).

* Become familiar with using the ASU [RStudio server](https://mathr.math.appstate.edu/). Use your Appstate user name and password to log in.  You must be registered in the class to access the server.

* Complete _Intermediate R_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).

```{block, week2note, type='rmdnote'}
* A great way to get familiar with the RStudio server is to use it to take notes and create your own examples.
* R scripts can contain only code and comments. R Markdown files can contain customizable text and code.
```

```{block, test2, type='rmdexercise'}
Test yourself!

* Can you create and manipulate different kinds of vectors in R?
* Can you write a simple loop or function to perform a repeated task in R?
* Can you reproduce exercises in _Introduction to R_ and _Intermediate R_ for your own notes? 
```

```{block, week2optional, type='rmdoptional'}
Optional

* Explore _Intermediate R Practice_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).    
```


## Week 03 (Jan 30, Feb 01) {-}

* Read textbook [Section 27. R Markdown](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/r-markdown.html).

* Read textbook [Section 29. R Markdown Formats](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/r-markdown-formats.html).

* Complete _Reporting with R Markdown_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).

* Complete _Working with the Rstudio IDE (Part I)_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).

```{block, week3note, type='rmdnote'}
* Additional information on R Markdown can be found at [`R Markdown` from ![](https://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/RStudio-Logo-Blue-Gray-125.png)](http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com)
```

```{block, test3, type='rmdexercise'}
Test yourself!

* Can you create headers, bold text, and italicized text in your documents? 
* Can you create links, lists, tables, or other special formats in your documents?
* Can you use inline code to make your documents dynamic for reproducible results?
* Can you configure code chunks to show only the results of code and not the code itself?
* Can you modify the document header to use different themes or create a table of contents?
* Think ahead: what else would would be useful to know how to do inside a Markdown document?
```

```{block, week3optional, type='rmdoptional'}
Optional

* Explore _Working with the Rstudio IDE (Part II)_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).    
```


## Week 04 (Feb 06, Feb 08) {-}

* Read textbook [Section 8. Workflow: Projects](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/workflow-projects.html).

* Read Chapters 1, 8, and 10-13 of Jenny Bryan's _[Happy Git and GitHub for the useR](http://happygitwithr.com/)_.

* Read the "[Git and GitHub](http://r-pkgs.had.co.nz/git.html)" chapter from Hadley Wickham's book _[R Packages](http://r-pkgs.had.co.nz/)_.

* Complete _Introduction to Git for Data Science_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).

```{block, week4note, type='rmdnote'}
* Git and GitHub can be frustrating at first. _Push_ yourself to _commit_ to learning and using version control.
* You may want to create a folder in your account (e.g., git_repositories) in which to organize any projects.
```

```{block, test4, type='rmdexercise'}
Test yourself!

* Can you create a version-controlled project using Git and GitHub to develop a portfolio of class notes and examples?
```


## Week 05 (Feb 13, Feb 15) {-}

* Read textbook [Section 5. Data Transformation](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/transform.html).

* Read textbook [Section 7. Exploratory Data Analysis](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/exploratory-data-analysis.html).

* Complete _Data Visualization in R_ on [(DataCamp)](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).

* Create and publish a basic personal [web page using R Markdown](http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/rmarkdown_websites.html) and [GitHub Pages](https://pages.github.com/).

     + Site YAML---controls the web site structure
     + INDEX page---the main page for your web site  
     + ABOUT page---a brief blurb about yourself or your web site
     + One OTHER page---for example, showcase your own research or a list of links
     + Use one `theme` and one `highlight` style discussed [HERE](https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/html_document_format.html) to customize the look of your page

```{block, week5note, type='rmdnote'}
* You can easily get additional skills practice by spending a few minutes a day doing Daily Practice modules on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), which you can access from your dashboard. Try starting with the _Introduction to R_ practice.
```

```{block, test5, type='rmdexercise'}
Test yourself!

* How often are you referring back to your own notes versus googling information or relying on outside resources?
```


## Week 06 (Feb 20, Feb 22) {-}

* Read textbook [Section 3. Data Visualization](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html).

* Complete _Data Visualization with `ggplot2` (Part 1)_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).

```{block, week6note, type='rmdnote'}
* The [`ggplot2`](http://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/) package is one component of the [`tidyverse`](https://www.tidyverse.org/)--- "an opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science" that share a common philosophy for data manipulation, exploration and visualization. It is the kernel of our course textbook _[R for Data Science](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/)_.
* Remember the RStudio [Cheat Sheets](https://www.rstudio.com/resources/cheatsheets/)! You may want to check out the _Data Visualization with `ggplot2`_ sheet.
```

```{block, test6, type='rmdexercise'}
Test yourself!

* Are you taking advantage of working with your classmates to build your own knowledge and explanatory skills?
* How could you build on your web site to showcase your knowledge and skills as a data scientist?
```


## Week 07 (Feb 27, Mar 01) {-}

* Read textbook [Section 28. Graphics for Communication](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/graphics-for-communication.html).

* Complete _Data Visualization with `ggplot2` (Part 2)_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).

* Peer review your classmates' personal web pages. More on this TBA!

```{block, week7note, type='rmdnote'}
* Winston Chang's _[R Graphics Cookbook](http://proquest.safaribooksonline.com.proxy006.nclive.org/9781449363086?uicode=appstate)_ contains instructions for many types of data visualizations using `ggplot2`.
```

```{block, test7, type='rmdexercise'}
Test yourself!

* Can you load a dataset in which you are interested and create interesting, useful, professional-quality visualizations?
* Can you update your web page with an interesting example of data visualization using your new data science skills?
```

```{block, week7optional, type='rmdoptional'}
Optional

* Explore _Data Visualization with `ggplot2` (Part 3)_ on [DataCamp](https://datacamp.com), via [AsULearn](https://asulearn.appstate.edu).
* In particular, you may be interested in trying ternary plots and the `maps` package.
```
